title: Finding the nearest proper correlation matrix
code: require(psych) ## Loading required package: psych cc2 <- psych::cor.smooth(cc) ## Warning in psych::cor.smooth(cc): Matrix was not positive definite, smoothing ## was done max(cc2) ## [1] 1

title: Finding the nearest proper correlation matrix
text: converting matrix valid correlation matrix, accurate corrgram can created:
code: library(sfsmisc) # nearcor uses 'identical' and says the matrix is not symmetric isSymmetric(cc) # TRUE ## [1] TRUE identical(cc, t(cc)) # FALSE ## [1] FALSE # round slightly to make it symmetric cc3 <- nearcor(round(cc,12))$cor max(cc3) ## [1] 1 require(corrgram) ## Loading required package: corrgram corrgram(cc2, lower=panel.cor) ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: corrgram package implementation correlograms. vignette reproduces figures Friendly (2002).

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: data 11 measures performance salary 263 baseball players 1986 baseball season United States. data used 1988 Data Expo Joint Statistical Meetings. first 6 rows data upper-left corner correlation matrix given .

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: Figure 2 shows two ways graphically display correlation matrix using panel.shade() panel.pie() functions.
code: vars2 <- c("Assists","Atbat","Errors","Hits","Homer","logSal",            "Putouts","RBI","Runs","Walks","Years") corrgram(baseball[,vars2], order=TRUE,          main="Baseball data PC2/PC1 order",          lower.panel=panel.shade, upper.panel=panel.pie,          diag.panel=panel.minmax, text.panel=panel.txt)

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: Figure 3 shows eigenvector plot correlation matrix. forms basis orderings variables corrgram Figure 4b next section, beginning “AtBat” moving counter-clockwise “Years”. Note: Eigenvectors unique change sign.
code: baseball.cor <- cor(baseball[,vars2], use='pair') baseball.eig <- eigen(baseball.cor)$vectors[,1:2] e1 <- baseball.eig[,1] e2 <- baseball.eig[,2] plot(e1,e2,col='white', xlim=range(e1,e2), ylim=range(e1,e2)) text(e1,e2, rownames(baseball.cor), cex=1) title("Eigenvector plot of baseball data") arrows(0, 0, e1, e2, cex=0.5, col="red", length=0.1)

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: figure 4a variables sorted alphabetical order given data. figure 4b, variables sorted according principal component ordering Figure 3 look possible clustering variables. surprising see times bat strongly correlated higher number hits higher number runs.
code: corrgram(baseball[,vars2], main="Baseball data (alphabetic order)") corrgram(baseball[,vars2], order=TRUE,          main="Baseball data (PC order)",          panel=panel.shade, text.panel=panel.txt)

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: Figure 5 shows corrgram numeric variables dataframe. Non-numeric columns data ignored.
code: corrgram(baseball, order=TRUE, main="Baseball data (PC order)")

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: Figure 6 shows corrgram automotive data 74 different models cars 1979. two obvious groups variables Note, arrangement slightly different Friendly.
code: corrgram(auto, order=TRUE, main="Auto data (PC order)")

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: inverse correlation matrix expresses conditional dependence independence variables. variables sorted order figure 4. One example interpretation : controlling variables, still large correlation Years log Salary.
code: rinv <- function(r){   # r is a correlation matrix   # calculate r inverse and scale to correlation matrix   # Derived from Michael Friendly's SAS code    ri <- solve(r)   s <- diag(ri)   s <- diag(sqrt(1/s))   ri <- s %*% ri %*% s   n <- nrow(ri)   ri <- ri * (2*rep(1,n) - matrix(1, n, n))   diag(ri) <- 1  # Should already be 1, but could be 1 + epsilon   colnames(ri) <- rownames(ri) <- rownames(r)   return(ri) }  vars7 <- c("Years", "logSal", "Homer", "Putouts", "RBI", "Walks",            "Runs", "Hits", "Atbat", "Errors", "Assists") cb <- cor(baseball[,vars7], use="pair") corrgram(-rinv(cb), main=expression(paste("Baseball data ", R^-1)))

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: Figure 8 shows partial independence corrgram automotive data, Price MPG partialed .
code: require(Matrix) # For block diagonal function ## Loading required package: Matrix partial <- function(r, xvar){   # r is a correlation matrix   # Calculate partial correlation of y|x   yvar <- setdiff(colnames(r), xvar)   ri <- r[yvar,yvar] - r[yvar,xvar] %*% solve(r[xvar,xvar]) %*% r[xvar,yvar]   s <- diag(ri)   s <- diag(sqrt(1/s))   ri <- s %*% ri %*% s   ri <- as.matrix(Matrix::bdiag(ri, r[xvar, xvar]))   diag(ri) <- 1  # Should already be 1, but could be 1 + epsilon   colnames(ri) <- rownames(ri) <- c(yvar, xvar)   return(ri) }  vars8a <- c("Gratio", "Rep78", "Rep77", "Hroom", "Trunk", "Rseat",             "Length", "Weight", "Displa", "Turn") vars8b <- c("MPG", "Price") vars8 <- c(vars8a, vars8b) auto.cor <- cor(auto[, vars8], use="pair") auto.par <- partial(auto.cor, vars8b) corrgram(auto.par,          lower.panel=panel.pie, upper.panel=panel.pie,          main="Auto data, partialing out Price,MPG")

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: Figure 11 provides another way display data, using ellipses loess lines. Long, narrow ellipses represent high correlations circular ellipses represent low correlations.
code: corrgram(baseball[,vars2], order=TRUE,          main="Baseball correlation ellipses",          panel=panel.ellipse,          text.panel=panel.txt, diag.panel=panel.minmax)

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: Demonstrate density panel, correlation confidence panel  Demonstrate panel.bar, panel.ellipse, panel.minmax, col.regions
code: corrgram(iris,          main="Iris data with example panel functions",          lower.panel=panel.pts, upper.panel=panel.conf,          diag.panel=panel.density) ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter corrgram(auto, order=TRUE,          main="Auto data (PC order)",          lower.panel=corrgram::panel.ellipse,          upper.panel=panel.bar, diag.panel=panel.minmax,          col.regions=colorRampPalette(c("darkgoldenrod4", "burlywood1",                                         "darkkhaki", "darkgreen")))

title: Examples for the corrgram package
text: example showing one way plot ratings data.
code: load(url("https://github.com/alexanderrobitzsch/sirt/blob/master/data/data.ratings3.rda?raw=true"))  # jitter first, so the upper/lower panels are symmetric data.ratings3 <- transform(data.ratings3,                            c2=jitter(crit2), c3=jitter(crit3),                            c4=jitter(crit4), c6=jitter(crit6))                             library(corrgram) panel.raters <- function (x, y, corr = NULL, col.regions, cor.method, ...) {   if (!is.null(corr))      return()   plot.xy(xy.coords(x, y), type = "p", ...)   abline(lm(y ~ x))   box(col = "lightgray") } corrgram(data.ratings3[,7:10], diag=panel.density, lower.panel=panel.raters, upper.panel=panel.conf) ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ## Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter sessionInfo() ## R version 4.4.1 (2024-06-14) ## Platform: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu ## Running under: Ubuntu 22.04.4 LTS ##  ## Matrix products: default ## BLAS:   /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/openblas-pthread/libblas.so.3  ## LAPACK: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/openblas-pthread/libopenblasp-r0.3.20.so;  LAPACK version 3.10.0 ##  ## locale: ##  [1] LC_CTYPE=C.UTF-8       LC_NUMERIC=C           LC_TIME=C.UTF-8        ##  [4] LC_COLLATE=C.UTF-8     LC_MONETARY=C.UTF-8    LC_MESSAGES=C.UTF-8    ##  [7] LC_PAPER=C.UTF-8       LC_NAME=C              LC_ADDRESS=C           ## [10] LC_TELEPHONE=C         LC_MEASUREMENT=C.UTF-8 LC_IDENTIFICATION=C    ##  ## time zone: UTC ## tzcode source: system (glibc) ##  ## attached base packages: ## [1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base      ##  ## other attached packages: ## [1] Matrix_1.7-0  corrgram_1.14 knitr_1.48    ##  ## loaded via a namespace (and not attached): ##  [1] digest_0.6.36     desc_1.4.3        R6_2.5.1          fastmap_1.2.0     ##  [5] xfun_0.45         lattice_0.22-6    cachem_1.1.0      htmltools_0.5.8.1 ##  [9] rmarkdown_2.27    lifecycle_1.0.4   cli_3.6.3         grid_4.4.1        ## [13] pkgdown_2.1.0     sass_0.4.9        textshaping_0.4.0 jquerylib_0.1.4   ## [17] systemfonts_1.1.0 compiler_4.4.1    highr_0.11        tools_4.4.1       ## [21] ragg_1.3.2        evaluate_0.24.0   bslib_0.7.0       yaml_2.3.9        ## [25] jsonlite_1.8.8    rlang_1.1.4       fs_1.6.4

code: @Manual{,   title = {corrgram: Plot a Correlogram},   author = {Kevin Wright},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.14, http://kwstat.github.io/corrgram/},   url = {https://kwstat.github.io/corrgram/}, }

title: Plot a Correlogram
text: Homepage: https://kwstat.github.io/corrgram Repository: https://github.com/kwstat/corrgram corrgram package provides simple way create correlograms raw data correlation matrix.

title: Plot a Correlogram
text: Stable, well-tested, widely used. Extensive examples show customize display.

title: Plot a Correlogram
code: # Install the released version from CRAN: install.packages("corrgram")  # Install the development version from GitHub: install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("kwstat/corrgram")

title: Plot a Correlogram
code: require(corrgram) corrgram(mtcars, order=TRUE, lower.panel=panel.shade, upper.panel=panel.pie,          text.panel=panel.txt, main="mtcars")

title: Baseball Hitter's Data — baseball
text: data frame 322 observations following 22 variables. Name hitter/player's name League Player's league (American/National) beginning 1987 Team Player's team beginning 1987 Position Player's position 1986: 1B=First base, 2B=Second base, 3B=Third base, C=Catcher, =Outfild, DH=Designated hitter, SS=Short stop, UT=Utility Atbat Number times bat 1986 Hits Number hits 1986 Homer Number home runs 1986 Runs Number runs 1986 RBI Runs batted 1986 Walks Number walks 1986 Years Number years major leagues Atbatc Number times bat career Hitsc Number hits career Homerc Number home runs career Runsc Number runs career RBIc Number Runs Batted career Walksc Number walks career Putouts Number putouts 1986 Assists Number assists 1986 Errors Number errors 1986 Salary Annual salary (thousands) opening day 1987 logSal Log salary

title: Baseball Hitter's Data — baseball
code: vars2 <- c("Assists","Atbat","Errors","Hits","Homer","logSal",            "Putouts","RBI","Runs","Walks","Years") corrgram(baseball[,vars2],          lower.panel=panel.shade, upper.panel=panel.pie)

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
text: corrgram function produces graphical display correlation matrix, called correlogram.  cells matrix can shaded colored show correlation value. Automatic variable reordering can used improve visualization.

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
code: corrgram(   x,   type = NULL,   order = FALSE,   labels,   panel = panel.shade,   lower.panel = panel,   upper.panel = panel,   diag.panel = NULL,   text.panel = textPanel,   label.pos = c(0.5, 0.5),   label.srt = 0,   cex.labels = NULL,   font.labels = 1,   row1attop = TRUE,   dir = "",   gap = 0,   abs = FALSE,   col.regions = colorRampPalette(c("red", "salmon", "white", "royalblue", "navy")),   cor.method = "pearson",   outer.labels = NULL,   ... )

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
text: x tall data frame one observation per row, correlation matrix. type Use 'data' 'cor'/'corr' explicitly specify 'x' data correlation matrix.  Rarely needed. order variables re-ordered? improve visualization placing similar variables next . Use TRUE "PCA" angular PCA-based re-ordering (see Friendly, 2002). 'seriation' package installed, distance-based method seriate can used. Examples "OLO" optimal leaf ordering, "GW", "HC", "MDS" (see Hahsler Buchta, 2008). labels Labels use (instead data frame variable names) diagonal panels. 'order' option used, vector labels also appropriately reordered function. panel Function used plot contents panel. lower.panel, upper.panel Separate panel functions used /diagonal. diag.panel, text.panel Panel function used diagonal. label.pos Horizontal vertical placement label diagonal panels. label.srt String rotation diagonal labels. cex.labels, font.labels Graphics parameter diagonal panels. row1attop TRUE diagonal like " \ ", FALSE diagonal like " / ". dir Use dir="left" instead 'row1attop'. gap Distance panels. abs Use absolute value correlations clustering?  Default FALSE. col.regions function returning vector colors. cor.method Correlation method use panel functions.  Default 'pearson'.  Alternatives: 'spearman', 'kendall'. outer.labels list form 'list(bottom,left,top,right)'. 'bottom=TRUE' (example), variable labels added along bottom outside edge. control, use 'bottom=list(labels,cex,srt,adj)', 'labels' vector variable labels, 'cex' affects size, 'srt' affects rotation, 'adj' affects adjustment labels. Defaults: 'labels' uses column names; cex=1'; 'srt=90' (bottom/top), 'srt=0' (left/right); 'adj=1' (bottom/left), 'adj=0' (top/right). ... Additional arguments passed plotting methods.

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
text: correlation matrix used plotting returned. 'order' 'abs' arguments affect returned value.

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
text: Note: Use 'col.regions' argument specify colors. Non-numeric columns data ignored. -diagonal panels specified panel.pts, panel.pie, panel.shade, panel.fill, `panel.bar, panel.ellipse, panel.conf. panel.cor. Diagonal panels specified panel.txt, panel.minmax, panel.density. Use NULL panel omit drawing panel. function basically modification pairs.default function use customized panel functions. panel.conf function uses cor.test calculates pearson correlations.  Confidence intervals available cor.test methods (kendall, spearman). can create panel functions starting one included panel functions making suitable modifications.  Note way panel functions called inside main function, custom panel function must include arguments shown panel.pts function, even custom panel function use arguments! TODO: legend, grid graphics version.

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
text: Friendly, Michael.  2002.  Corrgrams: Exploratory Displays Correlation Matrices.  American Statistician, 56, 316–324. http://datavis.ca/papers/corrgram.pdf D. J. Murdoch E. D. Chow. 1996. Graphical Display Large Correlation Matrices.  American Statistician, 50, 178-180. Hahsler M, Hornik K, Buchta C. 2008. Getting things order: introduction R package seriation. Journal Statistical Software, 25(3), 1–34. ISSN 1548-7660, doi:10.18637/jss.v025.i03

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
text: Kevin Wright

title: Draw a correlogram — corrgram
code: # To reproduce the figures in Michael Friendly's paper, see the # vignette, or see the file 'friendly.r' in this package's # test directory.  # Demonstrate density panel, correlation confidence panel corrgram(iris, lower.panel=panel.pts, upper.panel=panel.conf,          diag.panel=panel.density) #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter   # Demonstrate panel.shade, panel.pie, principal component ordering vars2 <- c("Assists","Atbat","Errors","Hits","Homer","logSal",            "Putouts","RBI","Runs","Walks","Years") corrgram(baseball[vars2], order=TRUE, main="Baseball data PC2/PC1 order",          lower.panel=panel.shade, upper.panel=panel.pie)   # Use reordering options from package seriation (only available if #    package seriation is installed) if ("seriation" %in% rownames(installed.packages())) { corrgram(baseball[vars2], order= "OLO",           main="Baseball data with optimal leaf order",           lower.panel=panel.shade, upper.panel=panel.pie)  corrgram(baseball[vars2], order= "R2E",           main="Baseball data with rank 2 ellipse seriation",           lower.panel=panel.shade, upper.panel=panel.pie)  # the following seriation methods are available seriation::list_seriation_methods("dist") }   #>  [1] "ARSA"           "BBURCG"         "BBWRCG"         "Enumerate"      #>  [5] "GSA"            "GW"             "GW_average"     "GW_complete"    #>  [9] "GW_single"      "GW_ward"        "HC"             "HC_average"     #> [13] "HC_complete"    "HC_single"      "HC_ward"        "Identity"       #> [17] "MDS"            "MDS_angle"      "OLO"            "OLO_average"    #> [21] "OLO_complete"   "OLO_single"     "OLO_ward"       "QAP_2SUM"       #> [25] "QAP_BAR"        "QAP_Inertia"    "QAP_LS"         "R2E"            #> [29] "Random"         "Reverse"        "SGD"            "SPIN_NH"        #> [33] "SPIN_STS"       "Sammon_mapping" "Spectral"       "Spectral_norm"  #> [37] "TSP"            "VAT"            "isoMDS"         "isomap"         #> [41] "metaMDS"        "monoMDS"         # CAUTION: The latticeExtra package also has a 'panel.ellipse' function # that clashes with the same-named function in corrgram. In order to use # the right one, the example below uses 'lower.panel=corrgram::panel.ellipse'. # If you do not have latticeExtra loaded, you can just use # 'lower.panel=panel.ellipse'.  # Demonstrate panel.bar, panel.ellipse, panel.minmax, col.regions corrgram(auto, order=TRUE, main="Auto data (PC order)",          lower.panel=corrgram::panel.ellipse,          upper.panel=panel.bar, diag.panel=panel.minmax,          col.regions=colorRampPalette(c("darkgoldenrod4", "burlywood1",                                         "darkkhaki", "darkgreen")))   # 'vote' is a correlation matrix, not a data frame corrgram(vote, order=TRUE, upper.panel=panel.cor) #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter #> Warning: argument 1 does not name a graphical outer.labels=list(bottom=list(labels=labs,cex=1.5,srt=60),                            left=list(labels=labs,cex=1.5,srt=30,adj=c(1,0)))) mtext("Bottom", side=1, cex=2, line = -1.5, outer=TRUE, xpd=NA) title: corrgram 1.15 unpublished
text: Switch MIT license

title: corrgram 1.14 (2021-04-01)
text: CRAN release: 2021-04-29 seriation package moved Imports Suggests. makes corrgram lighter loading people. (Requested P.Kiener others) outer.labels argument improved default values.

title: corrgram 1.13 (2018-07-09)
text: CRAN release: 2018-07-09 Test coverage 95% using covr package. New panel.fill() function, omits diagonal lines. panel.conf panel.cor now auto-scale based absolute value correlations. panel.conf now allows cor.method="pearson" (default.) Fix issue #13.

title: corrgram 1.12 (2017-05-07)
text: CRAN release: 2017-05-07 New vignette invalid correlation matrix. corrgram() gives better warning symmetric matrix values outside [-1,1]. Added package logo github.

title: corrgram 1.11 (2017-04-03)
text: CRAN release: 2017-04-03 New argument outer.labels adding labels along outside edges corrgram. (Request Vanessa Bruat others.)

title: corrgram 1.10 (2016-11-09)
text: CRAN release: 2016-11-09 Function corrgram() now returns correlation matrix. Fixed custom label ordering order=TRUE M.Bruneaux. Began using testthat package.

title: corrgram 1.9 (2016-07-16)
text: CRAN release: 2016-07-16 New panel function panel.cor colored correlation values. Fixed minor bugs complete cases. Added cases tests directory.

title: corrgram 1.8 (2015-07-03)
text: CRAN release: 2015-07-03 Namespace changes due R devel changes.

title: corrgram 1.7 (2015-02-13)
text: CRAN release: 2015-02-13 Added seriate options.

title: corrgram 1.6 (2014-08-29)
text: CRAN release: 2014-08-29 Moved packages Depends Imports. Argument label.pos now defaults c(.5, .5) x,y positioning. (Request Evan Williams). New argument cor.method. (Request Evan Williams).

title: corrgram 1.5 (2013-08-29)
text: CRAN release: 2013-08-29 Updated references links. (Request Michael Friendly). Fixed small bug test correlation matrix. (Reported F. Rosa)

title: corrgram 1.4 (2012-11-07)
text: CRAN release: 2012-11-07 New argument col.regions specify panel colors. Re-worked examples section variety.

title: corrgram 1.3 (2012-08-15)
text: CRAN release: 2012-08-15 New panel function panel.bar. (Request dadrivr) Added example unclipped labels (test suite).

title: corrgram 1.2 (2012-03-28)
text: CRAN release: 2012-03-28 Small bug. Now accepts NA values correlation matrices, NAs caused missing combinations data cor(use=“pair”). Non-numeric columns data ignored. (Request JZ) New panel function panel.density. Test suite now includes corrgram inverse correlation, partial correlation matrices.

title: corrgram 1.1 (2011-10-20)
text: CRAN release: 2011-10-20 Added namespace.

title: corrgram 1.0 (2011-07-02)
text: CRAN release: 2011-07-02 New panel function panel.conf. New data set vote. New arguments dir, type, label.srt, title, abs. Now works either data.frame correlation matrix using type argument. New ordering method OLO using seriation package. Ordering can now done absolute value correlations.

title: corrgram 0.1 (2006-12-01)
text: CRAN release: 2006-11-30 First release CRAN.

title: corrgram 0.0 (2006-04-01)
text: Package development begins.
